results.title: Out of the past = Build my gallows high
results.creator_credit: Jacques Tourneur, Warren B. Duff and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: At the centre is the noir theme of a man’s destructive obsession with a femme fatale. The possibility of redemption is offered by the presence in a pastoral retreat of the safe, undemanding woman. The film’s special hallucinatory quality has its bases in Mitchum’s restrained playing and narration as the fated hero. Tourneur brings a downbeat, tragic other-worldliness to the complex flashback structure in which the past gradually overtakes the present. Photographer Nicholas Musuraca makes disconcerting use of deep shadow. Cast includes Robert Mitchum, Jane Greer, Kirk Douglas, Rhonda Fleming and Richard Webb. Based on the novel “Build my gallows high” by Geoffrey Homes.

results.title: Burnt by the sun = Utomlynonnye solntsem
results.creator_credit: Nikita Mikhalkov, Canal+, Camera One and Studio Trite
results.brief_description: Set in the Russian summer of 1936, “Burnt By the Sun” is a splendid film about the human damage wreaked by the Stalinist purges, and the betrayal of the revolutionary hopes of the Soviet people. Colonel Serguei Kotov is a military hero of the Bolshevik Revolution who is surrounded by loving family and comrades. In this ideal existence arrives a stranger, Dimitri, who represents the cold, indifferent face of Stalin’s terror. Slowly Kotov realises he is enmeshed in a senseless and violent maze from which there is no escape. Beautifully shot and executed, “Burnt By the Sun” is a study in the creeping paranoia and madness of a regime which has lost sight of its roots and lost sight of humanity. By encapsulating the drama of betrayal, corruption and totalitarianism in the personal struggle of Kotov to make sense of what it happening to himself and his family, this film offers both a powerful examination of the Stalinist era as well as acknowledging the impossibility of any one film, any one document being able to fully represent the horror of a period in which millions lost their lives, their dreams and their sanity. Academy Award winner for Best Foreign Language Film. In Russian with English subtitles.

results.title: O' Lucky man
results.creator_credit: Lindsay Anderson, Michael Medwin, Sam, Memorial and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Director Lindsay Anderson delivers a film that consciously plays with the telling of a story, beginning with sepia tone and the opening line ‘Once Upon a Time’. From then on we’re launched into technicolour and taken on the surreal journey of an ambitious young man in search of success who is constantly thwarted by the British Establishment. Mick Travis (Malcolm McDowell), a trainee coffee salesman, is both optimistic and naive. With his desire to be successful he eagerly jumps at any opportunity with wilful ignorance that inevitably leads him into the path of sinister digressions that challenge his good intentions. Each vignette plays on the genres of film from horror to comedy, realism to surrealism. The actors deftly play several roles each, their characters weave in and out of the story line to occasionally reconnect in this sprawling celebration of allegory.

results.title: Hawks and sparrows = Uccellacci e uccellini [Widescreen]
results.brief_description: In Pasolini’s picaresque serio-comic fable-essay-confession on the theme of social justice, a father and son set out to emulate St. Francis of Assissi’s mission to convert the birds to Christianity. Wandering the Italian landscape, they encounter a wise talking crow, who follows them along retelling left wing parables. Cast includes Toto and Ninetto Davoli. Musical score by Ennio Morricone.

results.title: Once upon a time in the west = C'era una volta il West [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Sergio Leone, Fulvio Morsella, San Marco, Rafran and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Leone took classic themes of the western revenge story and the coming to the Frontier of civilisation in the form of the railroad and reshaped them into a fresco-like narrative neither revisionist nor traditional. Western stereotypes are abstracted in a West so self-consciously relocated in fable and fantasy that it has been suggested by David Thomson that Leone at heart harboured a contempt for the genre. He and his writers certainly brought European sensibility to bear on American classicism frequently citing classic Hollywood westerns while dilating time and lingering on atmospherics at the expense of cause and effect, clarity and classical economy. Essential to the film’s affect is a symmetry between image and music (Morricone’s four basic musical themes were used to pace and construct scenes throughout the shooting) in an operatic “dance of death” in which “the arias are not sung, they are stared”. Cast includes Claudia Cardinale, Henry Fonda, Jason Robards, Charles Bronson and Gabriele Ferzetti.

results.title: The Eel = Unagi
results.creator_credit: Shohei Imamura, Hisa Lino, Imamura Productions, KSS Films, Satellite Cinema and Shochiku
results.brief_description: The Eel begins with the main character - Takuro Yamashita (Koji Yakusho) coming home early from a fishing trip to catch his wife committing adultery. He stabs her to death and then hands himself in to the police. The credits to the film commence, where it is revealed that Yamashita has just been released after eight years in prison. He carries with him a pet eel who has been his main companion in prison. Yamashita buys a dilapidated barber shop in a small rural town where he assumes he will be left alone. Soon, however, he is befriended by the assorted local characters who hang around his shop. Then he saves the life of Keiko Hattori (Misa Shimizu), a woman attempting to commit suicide to escape her manipulative fiance and her mad mother - and who also happens to resemble his murdered wife. The lives of these two escapees soon become entwined. Winner of the 1997 Cannes Palme d’Or, Shohei Imamura’s film masterfully balances humour and surreal imagery with a tale of redemption and love. The film bristles with the tension of Yamashita’s constant potential for violence and the surprising comical twists of his journey. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Across the Pacific
results.creator_credit: John Huston, Jack Saper, Jerry Wald, First National Pictures and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Adapted from the ‘Saturday Evening Post’ serial of the same name name by Robert Carson, this taut World War II thriller reunites the stars of John Huston’s earlier hit,’ The Maltese Falcon’. Humphrey Bogart plays Rick Leland, a tough, cynical Army officer given a bogus dishonorable discharge and sent undercover to hook up with Japanese sympathisers on the eve of Pearl Harbour. Aboard a freighter bound for the Orient, he plays a ticklish game of matching wits with the enigmatic Dr. Lorenz (Sidney Greenstreet), spiced by the presence of the mysterious and beautiful Alberta Marlow (Mary Astor). Huston made this film the year after making his directorial debut with ‘The Maltese Falcon’, and like that classic, this film is full of cool and subtle characters, sharp dialogue, and a plot chock full of twists and turns.

results.title: Nights of Cabiria = Le Notti di Cabiria
results.creator_credit: Federico Fellini, Dino De Laurentiis and De Laurentiis Entertainment Group
results.brief_description: Nights of Cabiria is Fellini’s bitter-sweet account of a resilient Roman prostitute desperate to find love and respect in marriage. Cabiria, played by Fellini’s wife Giulietta Masina, is the prostitute with a heart of gold who is in love with love. Endlessly searching for true love, Cabiria is continually disappointed by men - abused, deceived and betrayed - but she never loses hope. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Ugly, dirty and bad = Brutti, sporchi e cattivi
results.creator_credit: Ettore Scola, Carlo Ponti and Compagnia Cinematografica Champion
results.brief_description: Director Ettore Scola focuses on a large dysfunctional family living in a shanty town on the outskirts of Rome. The stingy patriarch, Giacinto, is personally wealthy but morally bankrupt, and his repulsive view of life trickles down to every member of his clan. Not content with corrupting his own flesh and blood, Giacinto spreads his philosophy throughout the entire village, where he functions as slumlord. Although the surroundings and characters exist at the lowest level of society, their misery is very funny at times, imbued with enormous energy in a daily fight to maintain their survival. In Italian with English subtitles. Cast includes Nino Manfredi, Maria Bosco and Giselda Castrini.

results.title: Trauma
results.brief_description: A mysterious 16 year old girl named Aura (played by Dario Argento’s daughter Asia) is saved from jumping off a bridge by David, a young graphic artist (Christopher Rydell). The troubled girl has just escaped from a sanatorium run by the sinister Dr. Judd (Frederick Forrest) and is terrified about going back there. Meanwhile a deranged killer who gruesomely dispatches his victims by decapitation is terrorizing the city. Aura finds herself safely back at her parents, an odd pair of Russian mystics (Piper Laurie and Dominique Serrand) but soon finds her life is in danger as the killer is somehow linked to her past. Argento’s delirious thriller threatens to derail at certain times, mixing explicit violence, eating disorders, romance and mysticism. However his stylish direction holds it together for the most part, only faltering right at the end with a ludicrous and extraneous credit sequence. Cast also includes Brad Dourif, James Russo and Laura Johnson. See also ‘Deep red’ (1975), ‘Suspiria’ (1977) and ‘The Bird with the crystal plumage’ (1970).

Cast also includes Brad Dourif, James Russo and Laura Johnson. See also ‘Deep red’ (1975), ‘Suspiria’ (1977) and ‘The Bird with the crystal plumage’ (1970).
